item.title: Sarah Everard: Met PC Wayne Couzens charged with murder
item.description: Wayne Couzens is accused of kidnapping and murdering the 33-year-old who was last seen in south London.

item.title: Sarah Everard vigil organisers lose court challenge
item.description: A High Court judge refuses to intervene in the action against the police ban on the event.

item.title: Covid-19 pandemic: Italy to shut shops and schools amid infection spike
item.description: Shops, restaurants and schools will be closed across most of the country on Monday.

item.title: Covid-19: UK national day of reflection to be held on 23 March
item.description: Politicians back a charity's plan to commemorate a year since the first national restrictions began.

item.title: University of Manchester students pass vote of no confidence in boss
item.description: Critics say Dame Nancy Rothwell's position at the University of Manchester is "completely untenable".

item.title: Cuomo: Pressure mounts as senators tell New York governor to quit
item.description: Governor Andrew Cuomo has been accused of sexual misconduct by seven women, allegations he denies.

item.title: House builders 'should drop appalling gagging orders'
item.description: Developers who carry out repair work should not require non-disclosure agreements, says an MP.

item.title: Minneapolis to pay murdered George Floyd family $27m
item.description: The settlement comes as jury selection resumes for the murder trial of ex-officer Derek Chauvin

item.title: Covid-19: 48,000 businesses sign up for rapid testing
item.description: All companies in England can register for workplace coronavirus testing until 31 March.

item.title: Premier League hopes fans can return for final two rounds of games
item.description: The Premier League plans to have fans at the final two rounds of matches this season, says chief executive Richard Masters.

item.title: School poverty cash at risk in count change
item.description: "Grave concerns" from schools that a rule change could lower cash for the disadvantaged.

item.title: Covid and schools: First week finished after children in England return
item.description: The BBC visited one school in Lincolnshire to see how its staff and children were coping on week one.

item.title: Newspaper headlines: Vigils 'to defy' ban and Easter jabs for over-40s
item.description: Developments in Sarah Everard's murder case and the planned vigils are carried in Saturday's papers.

item.title: Would you scrap your car for public transport credits?
item.description: A scheme in the Midlands is encouraging people to scrap their cars to get public transport credits.

item.title: India: How eating online is bringing women money - and freedom
item.description: Some Indian women are taking advantage of the popularity of online eating shows to become financially independent.

item.title: The Jaiy Twins: ‘We love proving people wrong’
item.description: Twin dancers Taitlyn and Kaylee Jaiy say discrimination as they were growing up made them hungrier to succeed.

item.title: Week in pictures: 6 - 12 March 2021
item.description: A selection of powerful images taken around the world this week.

item.title: Imagine Dragons: How a text saved singer Dan Reynolds' marriage
item.description: The singer was on his way to sign divorce papers when his wife sent a message that put them back on track.

item.title: How many attacks on women are there?
item.description: The disappearance of Sarah Everard has led to a conversation about the violence faced by women.

item.title: Hungry, angry and fleeing the horrors of war in northern Mozambique
item.description: A BBC team are the first international journalists to reach an area besieged by Islamist militants.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: The elite athletes training at home
item.description: Jacuzzi swims and pole vaulting over bins - getting ready for the Olympics and Paralympics has been creative.

item.title: Why the GameStop story is far from over
item.description: Huge swings in the share price show amateur investors are still taking on Wall Street.

item.title: Cartoon SuperTed set for new animation series
item.description: The teddy with magic powers was a favourite among royal princes and a generation of children.

item.title: Westwood moves into lead at Players as McIlroy misses cut
item.description: England's Lee Westwood hits a sensational bogey-free six-under 66 to move into the halfway lead at the Players Championship at TPC Sawgrass.

item.title: Newcastle snatch dramatic late draw with Aston Villa
item.description: Jamaal Lascelles scores in stoppage time to rescue a point for relegation-threatened Newcastle following a dramatic finale against Aston Villa at St James' Park.

item.title: 'The time is now or they're gone' - England face pivotal game against France
item.description: Before the 2021 Six Nations began many would have picked England v France as a pivotal game. It is, but for different reasons than expected.

item.title: Archer will 'do everything in my power' to play in T20 World Cup & Ashes
item.description: England bowler Jofra Archer says he must "take care" of his elbow injury if he wants to play a full part in the Twenty20 World Cup and the Ashes this year.

item.title: Zoe Atkin: British 18-year-old wins halfpipe bronze at World Championships
item.description: British freestyle skier Zoe Atkin claims halfpipe bronze at the World Championships in Aspen, USA.

item.title: Manager Wilder set to leave bottom club Sheffield Utd
item.description: Sheffield United manager Chris Wilder is set to leave his role after almost five years in charge.

item.title: Football Focus: Son Heung-min says Spurs need to keep their form for 'massive' north London derby
item.description: Tottenham Hotspur's Son Heung-min tells Football Focus Spurs need to keep their form ahead of Sunday's "massive" north London derby against Arsenal.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Wales and Scotland have announced the easing of restrictions on people meeting

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: The government says it may still be too early to book summer holidays abroad.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: Covid: What are the new rules for schools?
item.description: All students in England can now return to classrooms, but how will Covid testing work?

item.title: What happens if I don't get the Covid vaccine?
item.description: There are multiple coronavirus vaccines being rolled out in countries across the UK and around the world. What happens if you don't want it?

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 23 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being mass tested for new variants?
item.description: The government hopes "surge" testing will reduce transmission of new variants of Covid-19.

item.title: What are the Brazil, South Africa and UK variants and will vaccines work?
item.description: More cases are being found in the UK, including a variant first seen in Brazil.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pubs, hairdressers and gyms open?
item.description: Lockdown is being eased in England. When will services like hairdressers, pubs and gyms open?

item.title: Coronavirus: How does the test-and-trace system work?
item.description: MPs have said the government's test-and-trace system is too expensive and hasn't helped fight the pandemic.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Two approved Covid vaccines are being rolled out across the UK. So when might you get one?

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: What are the new rules for testing and hotel quarantine?
item.description: Travellers going to and from the UK face a growing number of restrictions.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Coronavirus testing: How to do a lateral flow test at home
item.description: Coronavirus lateral flow tests are free and provide a quick result within 30 minutes. But how do you do one?

item.title: Covid: Can you catch the virus outside?
item.description: The risks of catching Covid indoors are well-known, but what are the chances of being infected outdoors?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: As the UK cautiously unlocks, experts will review the evidence on when and where masks are needed.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the care home visiting rules in England?
item.description: New guidance gives hope to relatives wanting to visit care homes.

item.title: How could children make up for lost school time?
item.description: A massive task lies ahead for schools as they try to make up for teaching time lost during the pandemic.

item.title: Coronavirus, schools and children - what are the risks?
item.description: How much do children contribute to the spread of Covid?

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Covid-19: How did Saxmundham end up as the 'most-vaccinated' area?
item.description: Can other areas learn "a good lesson" from the vaccination success of a small corner of Suffolk?

item.title: Covid: How to deal with lockdown social anxiety
item.description: Lockdown easing has lead to excitement, but anxiety for some about how to deal with normal life.

item.title: Rayleigh: Bin lorry emptied on street as fire breaks out
item.description: The blaze is believed to have been caused by discarded batteries, a fire service says.

item.title: Wartime love letters discovered under Scarborough hotel floorboards
item.description: Archaeologists hope to find out who the mystery sweethearts were after the discovery in Scarborough.

item.title: Winchcombe meteorite: Cotswold town reacts to space rock discovery
item.description: A home in a Gloucestershire town was hit by the most valuable space rock ever to fall on the UK.

item.title: Abducted, shackled and forced to marry at 12
item.description: Up to 1,000 Christian, Hindu and Sikh girls are abducted in Pakistan every year, then forced to convert to Islam, and to marry.
